question_text: An 81-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for chest pain. During the evaluation, he becomes unresponsive.ECG is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is shown on this patient's ECG?
critique: This patient's ECG demonstrates ventricular fibrillation (Option D). The ECG has no identifiable organized ventricular waveforms but instead shows bizarre, irregular, and random waves. Although polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (e.g., torsades de pointes) can show highly variable QRS complexes as the axis of the rhythm rotates, there is still recognizable ventricular activity. Similarly, both accelerated junctional rhythm and monomorphic ventricular tachycardia have easily recognizable and discrete ventricular waveforms.
